intro: Antirrhinum majus subsp. cirrhigerum, commonly known as the redflower toadflax, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It features upright, branched stems that bear clusters of tubular, two-lipped flowers, typically in shades of red, orange, or yellow. The leaves are lance-shaped and arranged oppositely along the stem, with a hairy texture. This species is adapted to well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for garden cultivation.
